org.lightsleep

Class Sql<E>

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.lightsleep.Sql<E>
  • Type Parameters:
    E - the type of the entity related to the main table
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Cloneable, SqlEntityInfo<E>

    public class Sql<E>
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Cloneable, SqlEntityInfo<E>
    The class to build and execute SQLs.
    Java Example
     var contacts = new ArrayList<>();
 Transaction.execute(conn ->
     new Sql<>(Contact.class)
         .where("{lastName}={}", "Apple")
         .connection(conn)
         .select(contacts::add)
 );
    Groovy Example
     List<Contact> contacts = []
 Transaction.execute {
     new Sql<>(Contact)
         .where('{lastName}={}', 'Apple')
         .connection(it)
         .select({contacts << it})
 }
    Generated SQL
     SELECT id, lastName, firstName, ... FROM Contact WHERE lastName='Apple'
    Since:
    1.0.0
    Author:
    Masato Kokubo

      • queryName

        public java.lang.String queryName()
        Returns the subquery name in the WITH clause.

        Returns an empty string ("") if this object is not used in the WITH clause; Otherwise, if the constructor argument has a table alias, returns it, a name based on the order of WITH clauses (W1, W2, W3, ...) otherwise.

        Returns:
        the subquery name in the WITH clause
        Since:
        4.0.0

      • columns

        public Sql<E> columns(java.lang.String... propertyNames)
        Specifies target columns for SELECT and UPDATE SQL.

        Also sets them if they are not set in Sql objects set by the from, union or unionAll methods,

        You can also be specified "*" or "<table alias>.*". If this method is not invoked it will be in the same as "*" is specified.

        Java Example 1
         var contacts = new ArrayList<Contact>();
 Transaction.execute(conn ->
     new Sql<>(Contact.class)
         .columns("lastName", "firstName")
         .where("{lastName}={}", "Apple")
         .connection(conn)
         .select(contacts::add)
 );
        Groovy Example 1
         List<Contact> contacts = []
 Transaction.execute {
     new Sql<>(Contact)
         .columns('lastName', 'firstName')
         .where('{lastName}={}', 'Apple')
         .connection(it)
         .select({contacts << it})
 }
        Java Example 2
         var contacts = new ArrayList<Contact>();
 var phones = new ArrayList<Phone>();
 Transaction.execute(conn ->
     new Sql<>(Contact.class, "C")
         .innerJoin(Phone.class, "P", "{P.contactId}={C.id}")
         .columns("C.id", "P.*")
         .connection(conn)
         .<Phone>select(contacts::add, phones::add)
 );
        Groovy Example 2
         List<Contact> contacts = []
 List<Phone> phones = []
 Transaction.execute {
     new Sql<>(Contact, 'C')
         .innerJoin(Phone, 'P', '{P.contactId}={C.id}')
         .columns('C.id', 'P.*')
         .connection(it)
         .<Phone>select({contacts << it}, {phones << it})
 }
        Parameters:
        propertyNames - an array of property names related to the columns
        Returns:
        this object
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if propertyNames or any element of propertyNames is null
        See Also:
        columns(Collection), columns(Class), getColumns()

      • expression

        public Sql<E> expression(java.lang.String propertyName,
                         Expression expression)
        Associates the property with the specified expression.

        If expression is empty, releases the previous association of propertyName.

        Java Example
         var contacts = new ArrayList<Contact>();
 Transaction.execute(conn ->
     new Sql<>(Contact.class)
         .expression("firstName", "'['||{firstName}||']'")
         .where("{lastName}={}", "Orange")
         .connection(conn)
         .select(contacts::add)
 );
        Groovy Example
         List<Contact> contacts = []
 Transaction.execute {
     new Sql<>(Contact)
         .expression('firstName', "'['||{firstName}||']'")
         .where('{lastName}={}', 'Orange')
         .connection(it)
         .select({contacts << it})
 }
        Parameters:
        propertyName - the property name
        expression - the expression
        Returns:
        this object
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if propertyName or expression is null
        See Also:
        getExpression(String)

      • expression

                         java.lang.String content,
                         java.lang.Object... arguments)
        Associates the property with the specified expression.

      • innerJoin

        public Sql<E> innerJoin(java.lang.Class<?> entityClass,
                        java.lang.String tableAlias,
                        Condition on)
        Add the information of the table that join with INNER JOIN.
        Java Example
         var contacts = new ArrayList<Contact>();
 var phones = new ArrayList<Phone>();
 Transaction.execute(conn ->
     new Sql<>(Contact.class, "C")
         .innerJoin(Phone.class, "P", "{P.contactId}={C.id}")
         .connection(conn)
         .<Phone>select(contacts::add, phones::add)
 );
        Groovy Example
         List<Contact> contacts = []
 List<Phone> phones = []
 Transaction.execute {
     new Sql<>(Contact, 'C')
         .innerJoin(Phone, 'P', '{P.contactId}={C.id}')
         .connection(it)
         .<Phone>select({contacts << it}, {phones << it})
 }
        Parameters:
        entityClass - the entity class related to the table to join
        tableAlias - an alias of the table to join
        on - the join condition
        Returns:

      • leftJoin

        public Sql<E> leftJoin(java.lang.Class<?> entityClass,
                       java.lang.String tableAlias,
                       Condition on)
        Add the information of the table that join with LEFT OUTER JOIN.
        Java Example
         var contacts = new ArrayList<Contact>();
 var phones = new ArrayList<Phone>();
 Transaction.execute(conn ->
     new Sql<>(Contact.class, "C")
         .leftJoin(Phone.class, "P", "{P.contactId}={C.id}")
         .connection(conn)
         .<Phone>select(contacts::add, phones::add)
 );
        Groovy Example
         List<Contact> contacts = []
 List<Phone> phones = []

     new Sql<>(Contact, 'C')
         .leftJoin(Phone, 'P', '{P.contactId}={C.id}')
         .connection(it)
         .<Phone>select({contacts << it}, {phones << it})
 }
        Parameters:

        tableAlias - an alias of the table to join
        on - the join condition
        Returns:
        this object
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if entityClass, tableAlias or on is null

      • where

        public Sql<E> where(Condition condition)
        Specifies the condition of the WHERE clause.
        Java Example
         var contacts = new ArrayList<Contact>();
 Transaction.execute(conn ->
     new Sql<>(Contact.class)
         .where("{birthday} IS NULL")
         .connection(conn)
         .select(contacts::add)
 );
        Groovy Example
         List<Contact> contacts = []

     new Sql<>(Contact)
         .where('{birthday} IS NULL')
         .connection(it)
         .select({contacts << it})
 }

        Returns:
        this object

        java.lang.NullPointerException - if condition is null

      • where

        public Sql<E> where(java.lang.String content,
                    java.lang.Object... arguments)
        Specifies the condition of the WHERE clause by an Expression.
        Java Example
         int id = 1;
 var contact = new Contact[1];
 Transaction.execute(conn ->
     contact[0] = new Sql<>(Contact.class)
         .where("{id}={}", id)
         .connection(conn).select().orElse(null)
 );
        Groovy Example
         int id = 1
 Contact contact
 Transaction.execute {
     contact = new Sql<>(Contact)
         .where('{id}={}', id)
         .connection(it)
         .select().orElse(null)
 }
        Parameters:
        content - the content of the Expression
        arguments - arguments of the Expression
        Returns:
        this object
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if content or arguments is null
        See Also:
        getWhere(), Condition.of(String, Object...)

      • where

        public <K> Sql<E> where(K entity)
        Specifies the condition of the WHERE clause by an EntityCondition.
        Java Example
         var contact = new Contact[1];
 Transaction.execute(conn ->
     contact[0] = new Sql<>(Contact.class)
         .where(new ContactKey(2))
         .connection(conn)
         .select().orElse(null)
 );
        Groovy Example
         Contact contact
 Transaction.execute {
     Contact key = new Contact()
     key.id = 2
     contact = new Sql<>(Contact)
         .where(key)
         .connection(it)
         .select().orElse(null)
 }
        Type Parameters:
        K - the type of the entity

        entity - the entity of the EntityCondition
        Returns:
        this object
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if entity is null
        See Also:
        getWhere(), Condition.of(Object)

      • where

        public <SE> Sql<E> where(java.lang.String content,
                         Sql<SE> subSql)
        Specifies the condition of the WHERE clause by a SubqueryCondition.
        Java Example
         var contacts = new ArrayList<Contact>();
 Transaction.execute(conn ->
     new Sql<>(Contact.class, "C")
         .where("EXISTS",
              new Sql<>(Phone.class, "P")
                  .where("{P.contactId}={C.id}")
                  .and("{P.content} LIKE {}", "0800001%")
         )
         .connection(conn)
         .select(contacts::add)
 );
        Groovy Example
         List<Contact> contacts = []
 Transaction.execute {
     new Sql<>(Contact, 'C')
         .where('EXISTS',
              new Sql<>(Phone, 'P')
                  .where('{P.contactId}={C.id}')
                  .and('{P.content} LIKE {}', '0800001%')
         )
         .connection(it)
         .select({contacts << it})
 }
        Type Parameters:
        SE - the type of the entity related to the subquery
        Parameters:
        content - the left part from the SELECT statement of a subquery
        subSql - the Sql object for the subquery
        Returns:
        this object
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if content or subSql is null
        See Also:
        where(Sql, String), getWhere(), Condition.of(String, Sql, Sql), SubqueryCondition(Expression, Sql, Sql)

      • with

        public Sql<E> with(Sql<?>... withSqls)
        Specifies WITH clauses.
        Java Example
         var nodes = new ArrayList<Node>();
 var nodeSql = new Sql<>(Node.class)
    .where("{name} LIKE {}", "%-%");
 Transaction.execute(conn ->
     new Sql<>(Node.class)
         .with(nodeSql)
         .from(nodeSql)
         .connection(conn)
         .select(nodes::add)
 );
        Groovy Example
         List<Node> nodes = []
 def nodeSql = new Sql<>(Node)
    .where('{name} LIKE {}', '%-%')
 Transaction.execute {
     new Sql<>(Node)
         .with(nodeSql)
         .from(nodeSql)
         .connection(it)
         .select({nodes << it})
 }
        Parameters:
        withSqls - Sql objects for WITH clauses
        Returns:
        this object
        Since:
        4.0.0
        See Also:
        getWithSqls(), isWithSql(), recursive(Sql), getRecursiveSql(), isRecursiveSql()

        Returns:

      • recursive

        public Sql<E> recursive(Sql<?> recursiveSql)
        Specifies RECURSIVE SQL.
        Java Example
         var nodes = new ArrayList<Node>();
 var nodeSql = new Sql<>(Node.class).where(rootNode)
     .recursive(new Sql<>(Node.class, "node").where("{node.parentId}={W1.id}"));
 Transaction.execute(conn ->
     new Sql<>(Node.class)
         .with(nodeSql)
         .from(nodeSql)
         .connection(conn)
         .select(nodes::add)
 );
        Groovy Example
         List<Node> nodes = []
 def nodeSql = new Sql<>(Node).where(rootNode)
     .recursive(new Sql<>(Node, 'node').where('{node.parentId}={W1.id}'))
 Transaction.execute {
     new Sql<>(Node)
         .with(nodeSql)
         .from(nodeSql)
         .connection(it)
         .select({nodes << it})
 }
        Parameters:
        recursiveSql - the Sql object for RECURSIVE SQL
        Returns:
        this object
        Since:
        4.0.0
        See Also:
        with(Sql...), getWithSqls(), isWithSql(), getRecursiveSql(), isRecursiveSql()

        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - unionAll method has already been invoked
        Since:
        3.1.0
        See Also:
        unionAll(Sql)

      • unionAll

        public Sql<E> unionAll(Sql<?> unionSql)
        Adds the Sql object that generate a SELECT SQL for a UNION ALL SQL component.
        Java Example
         var leaves = new ArrayList<Leaf>();
 Transaction.execute(conn ->
    new Sql<>(Leaf.class)
        .unionAll(new Sql<>(LeafA.class).where("{parentId}={}", rootNode.getId()))
        .unionAll(new Sql<>(LeafB.class).where("{parentId}={}", rootNode.getId()))
        .connection(conn)
        .select(leaves::add)
 );
        Groovy Example
         List<Leaf> leaves = []
 Transaction.execute {
    new Sql<>(Leaf)
        .unionAll(new Sql<>(LeafA).where("{parentId}={}", rootNode.id))
        .unionAll(new Sql<>(LeafB).where("{parentId}={}", rootNode.id))
        .connection(it)
        .select({leaves << it})
 }
        Parameters:
        unionSql - the Sql object that generate a SELECT SQL for a UNION ALL SQL component
        Returns:
        this object
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - union method has already been invoked
        Since:
        3.1.0
        See Also:
        union(Sql)

      • doIf

        public Sql<E> doIf(boolean condition,
                   java.util.function.Consumer<Sql<E>> action)
        Executes action if condition is true.
        Java Example
         var contacts = new ArrayList<Contact>();
 Transaction.execute(conn ->
     new Sql<>(Contact.class, "C")
         .connection(conn)
         .doIf(!(conn.getDatabase() instanceof SQLite), Sql::forUpdate)
         .select(contacts::add)
 );
        Groovy Example
         List<Contact> contacts = []
 Transaction.execute {
     new Sql<>(Contact, 'C')
         .connection(it)
         .doIf(!(conn.database instanceof SQLite)) {it.forUpdate}
         .select({contacts << it})
 }
        Parameters:
        condition - the condition of execution
        action - the action
        Returns:
        this object
        See Also:
        doNotIf(boolean, Consumer), doElse(Consumer), doAlways(Consumer)

      • doNotIf

        public Sql<E> doNotIf(boolean condition,
                      java.util.function.Consumer<Sql<E>> action)
        Executes action if condition is false.
        Java Example
         var contacts = new ArrayList<Contact>();
 Transaction.execute(conn ->
     new Sql<>(Contact.class, "C")
         .connection(conn)
         .doNotIf(conn.getDatabase() instanceof SQLite, Sql::forUpdate)
         .select(contacts::add)
 );
        Groovy Example
         List<Contact> contacts = []
 Transaction.execute {
     new Sql<>(Contact, 'C')
         .connection(it)
         .doNotIf(conn.database instanceof SQLite) {it.forUpdate}
         .select({contacts << it})
 }
        Parameters:
        condition - the condition of execution
        action - the action
        Returns:
        this object
        Since:
        3.0.0
        See Also:
        doIf(boolean, Consumer), doElse(Consumer), doAlways(Consumer)

      • doElse

        Parameters:
        elseAction - the action
        Returns:
        this object

      • select

        public void select(java.util.function.Consumer<? super E> consumer)
        Generates and executes a SELECT SQL that joins no tables.

        Adds following string to columns set if columns method is not invoked and innerJoin, leftJoin or rightJoin method invoked.

        • "<Main Table Alias>.*"
        Java Example
         var contacts = new ArrayList<Contact>();
 Transaction.execute(conn ->
     new Sql<>(Contact.class)
         .connection(conn)
         .select(contacts::add)
 );
        Groovy Example
         List<Contact> contacts = []
 Transaction.execute {
     new Sql<>(Contact)
         .connection(it)
         .select({contacts << it})
 }

        Caution: Call connection(ConnectionWrapper) method to specify the connection wrapper before invoking this method.

        Parameters:
        consumer - a consumer of the entities created from the ResultSet
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if consumer is null
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if a ConnectionWrapper is not set
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if a SELECT SQL without columns was generated
        RuntimeSQLException - if a SQLException is thrown while accessing the database, replaces it with this exception
        Since:
        2.0.0
        See Also:
        selectAs(Class, Consumer)

      • selectAs

        public <RE> void selectAs(java.lang.Class<RE> resultClass,
                          java.util.function.Consumer<? super RE> consumer)
        Generates and executes a SELECT SQL that joins no tables.

        Adds following string to columns set if columns method is not invoked and innerJoin, leftJoin or rightJoin method invoked.

        • "<Main Table Alias>.*"
        Java Example
         var contactNames = new ArrayList<ContactName>();
 Transaction.execute(conn ->
     new Sql<>(Contact.class)

     new Sql<>(Contact)
         .connection(it)
         .selectAs(ContactName, {contactNames << it})
 }

        Caution: Call connection(ConnectionWrapper) method to specify the connection wrapper before invoking this method.

        Type Parameters:
        RE - the type of the result entity
        Parameters:
        resultClass - the class of the argumrnt of consumer
        consumer - a consumer of the entities created from the ResultSet
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if resultClass or consumer is null
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if a ConnectionWrapper is not set
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if a SELECT SQL without columns was generated
        RuntimeSQLException - if a SQLException is thrown while accessing the database, replaces it with this exception
        Since:
        2.0.0
        See Also:
        select(Consumer)

      • select

        public <JE1> void select(java.util.function.Consumer<? super E> consumer,
                         java.util.function.Consumer<? super JE1> consumer1)
        Generates and executes a SELECT SQL that joins one table.

        Adds following strings to columns set if columns method is not invoked and innerJoin, leftJoin or rightJoin method invoked more than once.

        • "<Main Table Alias>.*"
        • "<Joined Table Alias>.*"
        Java Example
         var contacts = new ArrayList<Contact>();
 var phones   = new ArrayList<Phone>();
 Transaction.execute(conn ->
     new Sql<>(Contact.class, "C")
         .innerJoin(Phone.class, "P", "{P.contactId}={C.id}")
         .connection(conn)
         .<Phone>select(contacts::add, phones::add)
 );
        Groovy Example
         List<Contact> contacts = []
 List<Phone>   phones = []
 Transaction.execute {
     new Sql<>(Contact, 'C')
         .innerJoin(Phone, 'P', '{P.contactId}={C.id}')
         .connection(it)
         .select({contacts << it}, {phones << it})
 }

        Caution: Call connection(ConnectionWrapper) method to specify the connection wrapper before invoking this method.

        Type Parameters:
        JE1 - the type of the entity related to the joined table
        Parameters:
        consumer - a consumer of the entities related to the main table created from the ResultSet
        consumer1 - a consumer of the entities related to the joined table created from the ResultSet
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if consumer or consumer1 is null
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if joinInfo information is less than 1
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if a ConnectionWrapper is not set
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if a SELECT SQL without columns was generated
        RuntimeSQLException - if a SQLException is thrown while accessing the database, replaces it with this exception
        Since:
        2.0.0

      • select

        public <JE1,JE2> void select(java.util.function.Consumer<? super E> consumer,
                             java.util.function.Consumer<? super JE1> consumer1,
                             java.util.function.Consumer<? super JE2> consumer2)
        Generates and executes a SELECT SQL that joins two tables.

        Adds following strings to columns set if columns method is not invoked and innerJoin, leftJoin or rightJoin method invoked more than twice.

        • "<Main Table Alias>.*"
        • "<1st Joined Table Alias>.*"
        • "<2nd Joined Table Alias>.*"
        Java Example
         var contacts = new ArrayList<Contact>();
 var phones   = new ArrayList<Phone>();
 var emails   = new ArrayList<Email>();
 Transaction.execute(conn ->
     new Sql<>(Contact.class, "C")
         .innerJoin(Phone.class, "P", "{P.contactId}={C.id}")
         .innerJoin(Email.class, "E", "{E.contactId}={C.id}")
         .connection(conn)
         .<Phone, Email>select(contacts::add, phones::add, emails::add)
 );
        Groovy Example
         List<Contact> contacts = []
 List<Phone>   phones = []
 List<Email>   emails = []
 Transaction.execute {
     new Sql<>(Contact, 'C')
         .innerJoin(Phone, 'P', '{P.contactId}={C.id}')
         .innerJoin(Email, 'E', '{E.contactId}={C.id}')
         .connection(it)
         .select({contacts << it}, {phones << it}, {emails << it})
 }

        Caution: Call connection(ConnectionWrapper) method to specify the connection wrapper before invoking this method.

        Type Parameters:
        JE1 - the type of the entity related to the 1st joined table
        JE2 - the type of the entity related to the 2nd joined table
        Parameters:
        consumer - a consumer of the entities related to the main table created from the ResultSet
        consumer1 - a consumer of the entities related to the 1st joined table created from the ResultSet
        consumer2 - a consumer of the entities related to the 2nd joined table created from the ResultSet
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if consumer, consumer1 or consumer2 is null
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if join information is less than 2
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if a ConnectionWrapper is not set
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if a SELECT SQL without columns was generated
        RuntimeSQLException - if a SQLException is thrown while accessing the database, replaces it with this exception
        Since:
        2.0.0

      • select

        public <JE1,JE2,JE3> void select(java.util.function.Consumer<? super E> consumer,
                                 java.util.function.Consumer<? super JE1> consumer1,
                                 java.util.function.Consumer<? super JE2> consumer2,
                                 java.util.function.Consumer<? super JE3> consumer3)
        Generates and executes a SELECT SQL that joins three tables.

        Adds following strings to columns set if columns method is not invoked and innerJoin, leftJoin or rightJoin method invoked more than 3 times.

        • "<Main Table Alias>.*"
        • "<1st Joined Table Alias>.*"
        • "<2nd Joined Table Alias>.*"
        • "<3rd Joined Table Alias>.*"
        Java Example
         var contacts  = new ArrayList<Contact>();
 var phones    = new ArrayList<Phone>();
 var emails    = new ArrayList<Email>();
 var addresses = new ArrayList<Address>();
 Transaction.execute(conn ->
     new Sql<>(Contact.class, "C")
         .innerJoin(  Phone.class, "P", "{P.contactId}={C.id}")
         .innerJoin(  Email.class, "E", "{E.contactId}={C.id}")
         .innerJoin(Address.class, "A", "{A.contactId}={C.id}")
         .connection(conn)
         .<Phone, Email, Address>select(
             contacts::add, phones::add, emails::add, addresses::add)
 );
        Groovy Example
         List<Contact> contacts = []
 List<Phone>   phones = []
 List<Email>   emails = []
 List<Address> addresses = []
 Transaction.execute {
     new Sql<>(Contact, 'C')
         .innerJoin(Phone  , 'P', '{P.contactId}={C.id}')
         .innerJoin(Email  , 'E', '{E.contactId}={C.id}')
         .innerJoin(Address, 'A', '{A.contactId}={C.id}')
         .connection(it)
         .select(
             {contacts << it}, {phones << it}, {emails << it}, {addresses << it})
 }

        Caution: Call connection(ConnectionWrapper) method to specify the connection wrapper before invoking this method.

        Type Parameters:
        JE1 - the type of the entity related to the 1st joined table
        JE2 - the type of the entity related to the 2nd joined table
        JE3 - the type of the entity related to the 3rd joined table
        Parameters:
        consumer - a consumer of the entities related to the main table created from the ResultSet
        consumer1 - a consumer of the entities related to the 1st joined table created from the ResultSet
        consumer2 - a consumer of the entities related to the 2nd joined table created from the ResultSet
        consumer3 - a consumer of the entities related to the 3rd joined table created from the ResultSet
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if consumer, consumer1, consumer2 or consumer3 is null
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if join information is less than 3
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if a ConnectionWrapper is not set
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if a SELECT SQL without columns was generated
        RuntimeSQLException - if a SQLException is thrown while accessing the database, replaces it with this exception
        Since:
        2.0.0

      • select

        public <JE1,JE2,JE3,JE4> void select(java.util.function.Consumer<? super E> consumer,
                                     java.util.function.Consumer<? super JE1> consumer1,
                                     java.util.function.Consumer<? super JE2> consumer2,
                                     java.util.function.Consumer<? super JE3> consumer3,
                                     java.util.function.Consumer<? super JE4> consumer4)
        Generates and executes a SELECT SQL that joins four tables.

        Adds following strings to columns set if columns method is not invoked and innerJoin, leftJoin or rightJoin method invoked more than 4 times.

        • "<Main Table Alias>.*"
        • "<1st Joined Table Alias>.*"
        • "<2nd Joined Table Alias>.*"
        • "<3rd Joined Table Alias>.*"
        • "<4th Joined Table Alias>.*"
        Java Example
         var contacts  = new ArrayList<Contact>();
 var phones    = new ArrayList<Phone>();
 var emails    = new ArrayList<Email>();
 var addresses = new ArrayList<Address>();
 var urls      = new ArrayList<Url>();
 Transaction.execute(conn ->
     new Sql<>(Contact.class, "C")
         .innerJoin(  Phone.class, "P", "{P.contactId}={C.id}")
         .innerJoin(  Email.class, "E", "{E.contactId}={C.id}")
         .innerJoin(Address.class, "A", "{A.contactId}={C.id}")
         .innerJoin(    Url.class, "U", "{U.contactId}={C.id}")
         .connection(conn)
         .<Phone, Email, Address, Url>select(
             contacts::add, phones::add, emails::add,
             addresses::add, urls::add)
 );
        Groovy Example
         List<Contact> contacts = []
 List<Phone>   phones = []
 List<Email>   emails = []
 List<Address> addresses = []
 List<Url>     urls = []
 Transaction.execute {
     new Sql<>(Contact, 'C')
         .innerJoin(Phone  , 'P', '{P.contactId}={C.id}')
         .innerJoin(Email  , 'E', '{E.contactId}={C.id}')
         .innerJoin(Address, 'A', '{A.contactId}={C.id}')
         .innerJoin(Url    , 'U', '{U.contactId}={C.id}')
         .connection(it)
         .select(
             {contacts << it}, {phones << it}, {emails << it},
             {addresses << it}, {urls << it})
 }

        Caution: Call connection(ConnectionWrapper) method to specify the connection wrapper before invoking this method.

        Type Parameters:
        JE1 - the type of the entity related to the 1st joined table
        JE2 - the type of the entity related to the 2nd joined table
        JE3 - the type of the entity related to the 3rd joined table
        JE4 - the type of the entity related to the 4th joined table
        Parameters:
        consumer - a consumer of the entities related to the main table created from the ResultSet
        consumer1 - a consumer of the entities related to the 1st join table created from the ResultSet
        consumer2 - a consumer of the entities related to the 2nd join table created from the ResultSet
        consumer3 - a consumer of the entities related to the 3rd join table created from the ResultSet
        consumer4 - a consumer of the entities related to the 4th join table created from the ResultSet
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if consumer, consumer1, consumer2, consumer3 or consumer4 is null
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if join information is less than 4
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if a ConnectionWrapper is not set
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if a SELECT SQL without columns was generated
        RuntimeSQLException - if a SQLException is thrown while accessing the database, replaces it with this exception
        Since:
        2.0.0

      • select

        public java.util.Optional<E> select()
        Generates and executes a SELECT SQL and returns an Optional of the entity if searched, Optional.empty() otherwise.
        Java Example
         var contact = new Contact[1];
 Transaction.execute(conn ->
     contact[0] = new Sql<>(Contact.class)
         .where("{id}={}", 1)
         .connection(conn)
         .select().orElse(null)
 );
        Groovy Example
         Contact contact
 Transaction.execute {
     contact = new Sql<>(Contact)
         .where('{id}={}', 1)
         .connection(it)
         .select().orElse(null)
 }

        Caution: Call connection(ConnectionWrapper) method to specify the connection wrapper before invoking this method.

        Returns:
        an Optional of the entity if searched, Optional.empty() otherwise
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if a ConnectionWrapper is not set
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if a SELECT SQL without columns was generated
        RuntimeSQLException - if a SQLException is thrown while accessing the database, replaces it with this exception
        ManyRowsException - if more than one row searched
        Since:
        2.0.0
        See Also:
        selectAs(Class)

      • selectAs

        public <RE> java.util.Optional<RE> selectAs(java.lang.Class<RE> resultClass)
        Generates and executes a SELECT SQL and returns an Optional of the entity if searched, Optional.empty() otherwise.
        Java Example
         var contactName = new ContactName[1];
 Transaction.execute(conn ->
     contactName[0] = new Sql<>(Contact.class)
         .where("{id}={}", 1)
         .connection(conn)
         .selectAs(ContactName.class).orElse(null)
 );
        Groovy Example
         ContactName contactName
 Transaction.execute {
     contactName = new Sql<>(Contact)
         .where('{id}={}', 1)
         .connection(it)
         .selectAs(ContactName).orElse(null)
 }

        Caution: Call connection(ConnectionWrapper) method to specify the connection wrapper before invoking this method.

        Type Parameters:
        RE - the type of the result entity
        Parameters:
        resultClass - the class of entity to as a return value
        Returns:
        an Optional of the entity if searched, Optional.empty() otherwise
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - resultClass is null
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if a ConnectionWrapper is not set
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if a SELECT SQL without columns was generated
        RuntimeSQLException - if a SQLException is thrown while accessing the database, replaces it with this exception
        ManyRowsException - if more than one row searched
        Since:
        2.0.0
        See Also:
        select()

      • selectCount

        public int selectCount()
        Generates and executes a SELECT COUNT(*) SQL and returns the result.
        Java Example
         var count = new int[1];
 Transaction.execute(conn ->
     count[0] = new Sql<>(Contact.class)
         .connection(conn)
         .selectCount()
 );
        Groovy Example

 Transaction.execute {
     count = new Sql<>(Contact)
         .connection(it)
         .selectCount()
 }

        Caution: Call connection(ConnectionWrapper) method to specify the connection wrapper before invoking this method.

        Returns:
        the number of selected rows
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if a ConnectionWrapper is not set
        RuntimeSQLException - if a SQLException is thrown while accessing the database, replaces it with this exception
        Since:
        2.0.0

      • insert

        public int insert(java.lang.Iterable<? extends E> entities)
        Generates and executes INSERT SQLs for each element of entities.
        Java Example
         Transaction.execute(conn ->
     new Sql<>(Contact.class)
         .connection(conn)
         .insert(Arrays.asList(
             new Contact("Harumi", "Orange", LocalDate.of(2001, 2, 2)),
             new Contact("Mihaya", "Orange", LocalDate.of(2001, 2, 3)),
             new Contact("Asumi" , "Orange", LocalDate.of(2001, 2, 4))
         ))
 );
        Groovy Example
         Transaction.execute {
     new Sql<>(Contact)
         .connection(it)
         .insert([
             new Contact('Harumi', 'Orange', LocalDate.of(2001, 2, 2)),
             new Contact('Mihaya', 'Orange', LocalDate.of(2001, 2, 3)),
             new Contact('Asumi' , 'Orange', LocalDate.of(2001, 2, 4))
         ])
 }

        Caution: Call connection(ConnectionWrapper) method to specify the connection wrapper before invoking this method.

        Parameters:
        entities - an Iterable of entities
        Returns:
        the number of rows inserted
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if entities or any element of entities is null
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if a ConnectionWrapper is not set
        RuntimeSQLException - if a SQLException is thrown while accessing the database, replaces it with this exception
        Since:
        2.0.0

      • update

        public int update(E entity)
        Generates and executes an UPDATE SQL for the specified entity.

        If the condition of the WHERE clause is specified, updates by the condition.
        To update all rows of the target table, specify Condition.ALL to WHERE conditions.

        Java Example
         Transaction.execute(conn -> {
     var contact = new Contact[1];
     new Sql<>(Contact.class)
         .where("{firstName}={}", "Setoka")
         .and("{lastName}={}", "Orange")
         .connection(conn)
         .select(it -> contact[0] = it);

     contact[0].birthday = LocalDate.of(2017, 2, 1);
     new Sql<>(Contact.class)
         .columns("birthday")
         .connection(conn)
         .update(contact[0]);
 });
        Groovy Example
         Transaction.execute {
     Contact contact
     new Sql<>(Contact)
         .where('{firstName}={}', 'Setoka')
         .and('{lastName}={}', 'Orange')
         .connection(it)
         .select({contact = it})

     contact.birthday = LocalDate.of(2017, 2, 1);
     new Sql<>(Contact)
         .columns('birthday')
         .connection(it)
         .update(contact)
 }

        Caution: Call connection(ConnectionWrapper) method to specify the connection wrapper before invoking this method.

        Parameters:
        entity - the entity to be updated
        Returns:
        the number of rows updated
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if entity is null
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if a ConnectionWrapper is not set
        RuntimeSQLException - if a SQLException is thrown while accessing the database, replaces it with this exception
        Since:
        2.0.0

      • update

        public int update(java.lang.Iterable<? extends E> entities)
        Generates and executes UPDATE SQLs for each element of entities.

        Even if the condition of the WHERE clause is specified, new EntityCondition(entity) will be specified for each entity.

        Java Example
         Transaction.execute(conn -> {
     var contacts = new ArrayList<Contact>();
     new Sql<>(Contact.class)
         .where(Condition
             .of("{firstName}={}", "Setoka")
             .or("{firstName}={}", "Mihaya")
             .or("{firstName}={}", "Asumi")
         )
         .and("{lastName}={}", "Orange")
         .orderBy("{birthday}")
         .connection(conn)
         .select(contact -> contacts.add(contact));

         contacts.get(0).birthday = LocalDate.of(2017, 2, 2);
         contacts.get(1).birthday = LocalDate.of(2017, 2, 3);
         contacts.get(2).birthday = LocalDate.of(2017, 2, 4);
         new Sql<>(Contact.class)
             .columns("birthday")
             .connection(conn)
             .update(contacts);
 });
        Groovy Example
         Transaction.execute {
     List<Contact> contacts = []
     new Sql<>(Contact)
         .where(Condition
             .of('{firstName}={}', 'Setoka')
             .or('{firstName}={}', 'Mihaya')
             .or('{firstName}={}', 'Asumi')
         )
         .and('{lastName}={}', 'Orange')
         .orderBy('{birthday}')
         .connection(it)
         .select({contacts << it})

         contacts[0].birthday = LocalDate.of(2017, 2, 2)
         contacts[1].birthday = LocalDate.of(2017, 2, 3)
         contacts[2].birthday = LocalDate.of(2017, 2, 4)
         new Sql<>(Contact)
             .columns('birthday')
             .connection(it)
             .update(contacts)
 }

        Caution: Call connection(ConnectionWrapper) method to specify the connection wrapper before invoking this method.

        Parameters:
        entities - an Iterable of entities
        Returns:
        the number of rows updated
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if entities or any element of entities is null
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if a ConnectionWrapper is not set
        RuntimeSQLException - if a SQLException is thrown while accessing the database, replaces it with this exception
        Since:
        2.0.0

      • delete

        public int delete()
        Generates and executes a DELETE SQL.

        If the WHERE condition is not specified, dose not delete.
        To delete all rows of the target table, specify Condition.ALL to WHERE conditions.

        Java Example
         Transaction.execute(conn ->
     new Sql<>(Contact.class)
         .where(Condition.ALL)
         .connection(conn)
         .delete()
 );
        Groovy Example
         Transaction.execute {
     new Sql<>(Contact)
         .where(Condition.ALL)
         .connection(it)
         .delete()
 }

        Caution: Call connection(ConnectionWrapper) method to specify the connection wrapper before invoking this method.

        Returns:
        the number of rows deleted
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if a ConnectionWrapper is not set
        RuntimeSQLException - if a SQLException is thrown while accessing the database, replaces it with this exception
        Since:
        2.0.0
        See Also:
        Condition.ALL

         ])
